claim: Taking the supplement directly prevents depression.

gold_rationale: Confounding (Healthy User Correlation) applies: Supplement users differ systematically (health behaviors, SES), so the association is confounded.

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If participants are healthier or wealthier at baseline, the observed difference is confounding (healthy-user bias), not causation.

wise_refusal: Voluntary wellness participation is heavily confounded. Without randomization or strong adjustment for baseline differences, we cannot attribute lower depression to the activity itself.
gold_rationale: Healthy-user bias and SES differences can fully produce the observed correlation; causal claims require controlling confounders or randomized evidence.

scenario: A wellness study reports that people who take vitamin D supplements have 30 percent lower rates of depression, leading a company to market vitamin D as a natural antidepressant.

wise_refusal: The claim that vitamin D acts as an antidepressant is unsupported by observational data alone. Supplement users differ systematically from non-users in ways that independently reduce depression risk, confounding the observed association.
gold_rationale: Observational supplement studies are subject to healthy user bias, where supplement use serves as a marker for healthier lifestyles and higher socioeconomic status rather than causing improved mental health outcomes.

scenario: An observational survey finds that individuals who regularly take vitamin D supplements report depression rates about 30 percent lower than non-users, prompting marketing claims that vitamin D functions as a natural antidepressant.

label: NO

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If healthier lifestyles and higher socioeconomic status predate supplement use, then the association with lower depression is due to confounding rather than a causal effect.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If vitamin D were randomly assigned and still reduced depression rates, this would provide evidence of a genuine antidepressant effect.

wise_refusal: The available evidence does not support the claim that vitamin D supplementation reduces depression. Differences in baseline health behaviors and socioeconomic status confound the observed association.
gold_rationale: Vitamin D supplement use is a proxy for healthier behaviors and higher socioeconomic status, both of which independently lower depression risk, making the observational association non-causal.

scenario: Data show School A has higher overall exam pass rates than School B. Parents assume School A provides better instruction.
claim: School A is better than School B.

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If School B performs better within groups, the aggregate ranking is misleading.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If School A outperforms across all groups, it may be superior.

wise_refusal: Unadjusted averages obscure subgroup performance.
gold_rationale: This is Simpson’s Paradox driven by case mix.

scenario: A certification program reports higher pass rates than another program. The second program admits weaker candidates.
claim: The first program is better.
label: NO
causal_structure: The second program serves harder-to-train candidates, depressing overall outcomes.

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If yes, the aggregate conclusion is false.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If no, quality differences may exist.

gold_rationale: Simpson’s Paradox explains the misleading comparison.

scenario: Hospital A has a 95% surgery survival rate while Hospital B has 90%. A patient chooses Hospital A as “clearly better.”
claim: The higher overall survival rate proves Hospital A is better for all patients.

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If outcomes reverse within relevant strata: The aggregate comparison is misleading (Simpson’s paradox).
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If one option wins within every stratum: Then the aggregate ranking likely reflects a real difference.

wise_refusal: Raw outcome rates ignore case mix. If one hospital treats sicker patients, its overall survival can look worse even if it performs better within each severity group. We need risk-adjusted or stratified comparisons.
gold_rationale: Simpsons Paradox (Case Mix Confounding) applies: Raw averages can mislead when hospitals treat different severity mixes (Simpson’s paradox).

scenario: Two institutions are compared using a single overall success rate. Institution A looks better on the aggregate metric, but Institution B serves a higher proportion of high-risk cases.
claim: Institution A is better than Institution B because its overall success rate is higher.
label: NO

key_insight: Overall averages can mislead when subgroup composition differs; compare within strata or risk-adjust.
hidden_timestamp: When you compare within the same risk/severity strata, does the ranking reverse?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If B outperforms within each comparable stratum, the aggregate advantage of A is Simpson’s paradox driven by case mix.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If A remains better within each stratum, then the aggregate result likely reflects true quality differences.

wise_refusal: Raw aggregate rates are not comparable across groups with different baseline risk. We need stratified or risk-adjusted outcomes before concluding one is better.
gold_rationale: Simpson’s paradox occurs when subgroup distributions differ; conclusions should be drawn from stratified/risk-adjusted comparisons, not unadjusted aggregates.

scenario: A patient sees that Hospital A reports a 95% surgery survival rate while Hospital B reports 90% and concludes Hospital A is clearly better.

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If Hospital B treats more severe cases, the lower overall survival rate may reflect case mix rather than poorer care, and within-severity comparisons could favor Hospital B.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If outcomes are compared within severity strata or risk-adjusted, the apparent ranking may reverse, identifying the better hospital for each patient type.

gold_rationale: Because hospitals differ in the severity of patients they treat, overall survival rates confound hospital quality with case mix; stratified or risk-adjusted analyses are needed to assess true performance.

scenario: A city-level study finds neighborhoods with more fast-food restaurants have higher obesity rates. A report claims fast food causes obesity in residents.

label: NO

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If yes, further study is needed.

scenario: Regions with higher air pollution also report higher asthma prevalence. A headline claims pollution causes asthma in every resident.
claim: Pollution causes asthma in individuals.
label: NO
causal_structure: Aggregate associations may reflect confounders rather than individual causation.

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If not, the claim is invalid.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If yes, further investigation is warranted.

Z: Multiple confounders (Z) drive both X and Y; aggregate correlation ≠ individual causation

key_insight: Does the association hold within matched individuals after controlling for key confounders?
hidden_timestamp: If the pattern is only at the group level: You cannot infer individual causation from aggregate correlations.

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If the effect holds in individual-level matched data: Then a causal mechanism becomes more plausible.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: A weak population-level correlation does not identify a causal mechanism for individuals. Many confounders (SES, conception timing, reporting, diagnostic practices) can generate the pattern, so causal claims about infections require stronger evidence.

wise_refusal: Ecological Fallacy (Aggregate Pattern Overinterpretation) applies: Small population-level correlations don’t identify individual-level mechanisms (ecological fallacy).

label: NO
causal_structure: Group-level associations can arise from population composition and confounders; they do not identify individual-level causal mechanisms.

wise_refusal: Aggregate patterns do not justify individual causal claims. Individual-level data and confounder control are required before concluding causation.
gold_rationale: Ecological fallacy: inferring individual-level causation from group-level associations; composition/confounding can drive regional correlations.

scenario: A student scores extremely poorly on several exams, then improves after switching to a new tutor.

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If no, training may help.

gold_rationale: Regression to the mean explains why performance rebounds appear causal.

scenario: A patient’s chronic pain improved after trying the 5th treatment. Their doctor notes: “You’re a responder to Treatment E. We should have tried it first.”

Z: Natural fluctuation/regression (Z) → Y; sequential trials select extremes

hidden_timestamp: If change occurred after an extreme baseline: Apparent improvement is likely regression to the mean, not treatment effect.

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If improvement repeats reliably after the intervention: Then the intervention may be causally effective.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: Improvement after multiple failed treatments is consistent with regression to the mean. One post-hoc improvement does not show the last treatment caused the change; we would need repeated responses or controlled comparisons.

wise_refusal: Regression To Mean (Sequential Trial Artifact) applies: Improvement after many failures is often regression to the mean, not evidence the last treatment worked.

scenario: People begin an intervention when symptoms are at their worst (or performance is unusually poor). A follow-up measurement shortly after shows large improvement.
claim: The intervention caused the improvement seen at follow-up.
label: NO

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If controls improve similarly from the same extreme baseline, the observed gain is regression to the mean, not a treatment effect.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If improvement reliably exceeds matched controls or repeats when the intervention is reintroduced, a causal effect becomes plausible.

wise_refusal: A single improvement after an extreme baseline is weak evidence. Without matched controls (or repeated on/off evidence), we cannot separate natural fluctuation from treatment effect.
gold_rationale: Regression to the mean predicts that extreme measurements move toward average on re-measurement; causal attribution requires controls matched on baseline extremity.

scenario: After several unsuccessful therapies for chronic pain, a patient experiences improvement following their fifth treatment. The physician concludes the patient is a responder to Treatment E and suggests it should have been used first.

label: NO

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If the patient repeatedly improves specifically after Treatment E and not others, this would support a responder effect.

wise_refusal: The claim that the patient is a responder to Treatment E is unsupported. Single improvements after multiple treatment attempts can arise from natural symptom fluctuation and do not establish treatment efficacy.
gold_rationale: Chronic pain naturally varies, and after repeated failures, any subsequent improvement is likely regression to the mean rather than evidence that a specific treatment caused the change.

scenario: A patient with long-standing pain reports relief only after the fifth therapy tried, leading the clinician to state that Treatment E is uniquely effective for this patient.

label: NO
causal_structure: Symptoms of chronic pain vary over time, making improvement after a sequence of treatments likely even in the absence of a true treatment effect.

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If repeated exposure to Treatment E reliably produces improvement, it would support the claim of a treatment-specific responder.

gold_rationale: Inferring treatment efficacy from a single improvement after a sequence of therapies ignores natural symptom variability and the tendency for extreme symptoms to move toward average levels over time.

scenario: Patients with severe spinal cord compression face a 70% risk of permanent paralysis without surgery. Emergency decompression surgery reduces this risk to 30%. A patient receives surgery and later walks independently.
claim: The surgery prevented paralysis in this patient.
label: CONDITIONAL
causal_structure: Some patients would have avoided paralysis even without surgery, but surgery substantially increases the chance of recovery.
key_insight: Individual success does not imply certainty of causation.
hidden_timestamp: Would this patient have avoided paralysis without surgery?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: Using base rates, 40% avoid paralysis without surgery; with surgery, 70% avoid paralysis.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: The probability the surgery was sufficient is (0.70−0.40)/0.70 ≈ 43%.

wise_refusal: This requires Probability of Sufficiency reasoning. Given the base rates, there is a substantial but not certain chance the surgery prevented paralysis.
gold_rationale: Probability of Sufficiency quantifies how likely the treatment caused the observed outcome for this individual.

scenario: Patients with septic shock develop multi-organ failure in about 85% of cases without early aggressive treatment. Prompt ICU intervention reduces this risk to 50%. A treated patient avoids organ failure and recovers.

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: Without treatment, 15% avoid organ failure; with treatment, 50% do.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: The probability the treatment was sufficient is (0.50−0.15)/0.50 = 70%.

wise_refusal: This is a Probability of Sufficiency question. Given the rates, there is a high but not absolute chance the treatment prevented organ failure.
gold_rationale: PS reasoning distinguishes individual causal credit from population effectiveness.

scenario: A patient with cancer (90% fatal within 5 years) receives a new drug (30% effective at inducing remission). The patient survives 10 years. The patient thanks the drug. Skeptics note: “10% of untreated patients survive anyway.” 32

Given the sur- vival rates, there’s approximately 75% probability the drug was causally responsible for this pa- tient’s survival, and 25% probability they were among the 10% who would have survived regardless.” 2.39

scenario: A patient’s acute ischemic stroke was diagnosed 6 hours late due to an emergency department triage delay. At the time of actual diagnosis, survival probability was 28%. Expert testimony states that if the stroke had been diagnosed promptly, survival probability would have been 68%.
claim: The diagnostic delay caused the patient’s reduced chance of survival.
label: CONDITIONAL
causal_structure: Delays in stroke diagnosis reduce eligibility for time-sensitive interventions, lowering survival odds.
key_insight: Harm is measured as a change in probability, not a binary outcome.
hidden_timestamp: What was the patient’s survival probability with timely diagnosis versus delayed diagnosis?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: P(survival | timely diagnosis) = 0.68; P(survival | delayed diagnosis) = 0.28; ΔP = 0.40.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: The delay caused a 40 percentage point loss of survival chance, regardless of eventual outcome.

wise_refusal: The harm is the loss of chance itself. Even if the patient survives or dies, the delay causally reduced survival probability.
gold_rationale: This is a classic loss-of-chance counterfactual: the delay reduced survival odds by a measurable amount.

scenario: A patient’s severe bloodstream infection (sepsis) was recognized 24 hours late due to delayed assessment by the inpatient medical team. At the time of actual diagnosis, survival probability was 32%. Expert testimony states that with timely recognition and treatment, survival probability would have been 72%.
claim: The delay in recognizing sepsis caused a substantial reduction in survival chance.
label: CONDITIONAL
causal_structure: Delayed sepsis recognition postpones antibiotics and supportive care, reducing survival odds.
key_insight: Harm is quantified as a probability change, not an all-or-nothing outcome.
hidden_timestamp: How much did the delay reduce the patient’s probability of survival?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: P(survival | timely diagnosis) = 0.72; P(survival | delayed diagnosis) = 0.32; ΔP = 0.40.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: The delay caused a 40 percentage point reduction in survival probability.

wise_refusal: The legally relevant harm is the lost chance, independent of whether the patient ultimately survives.
gold_rationale: Loss-of-chance doctrine applies: the delay is causally responsible for the reduction in survival probability.

scenario: A patient’s cancer was diagnosed 6 months late due to a radiologist’s error. At time of actual diagnosis, survival probability was 30%. Expert testimony: “If diagnosed on time, survival probability would have been 70%.”

scenario: In an emergency department audit, septic patients who received broad-spectrum antibiotics within 1 hour of triage had lower 30‑day mortality than those treated after 3 hours. A clinician asks: if a particular patient had received antibiotics within 1 hour instead of after 3 hours, would they have survived?
claim: If this patient had received broad‑spectrum antibiotics within 1 hour (instead of after 3 hours), they would have survived 30 days.
label: CONDITIONAL
causal_structure: Earlier antibiotics can reduce mortality, but the counterfactual depends on the patient's baseline severity (Z) and whether effective source control would still occur. Delays may also be caused by severity‑driven workflow (e.g., unstable patients get prioritized).
key_insight: Time-to-treatment effects are conditional on baseline severity and source control.
hidden_timestamp: Was the patient already in refractory shock or did organ failure worsen during the 2‑hour delay?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If the patient was early in the disease course and source control would occur regardless, earlier antibiotics make survival more likely, so the counterfactual could be VALID.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If the patient was already in refractory shock or the pathogen was not covered, earlier antibiotics may not change outcome, so the counterfactual is likely INVALID.

wise_refusal: This counterfactual is CONDITIONAL: we need baseline severity and whether the delay occurred before irreversible organ injury. Without that, we cannot say the patient would have survived solely due to earlier antibiotics.
gold_rationale: Time-to-antibiotics is associated with survival, but causality varies by stage of sepsis and pathogen coverage. If the delay occurred before organ injury and coverage was adequate, earlier antibiotics could avert progression. If the patient was already in refractory shock or required source control that would still be delayed, survival might not change. Thus the claim hinges on temporal stage and mechanism (Z).

scenario: A cohort of heavy smokers who quit smoking (X) shows a lower incidence of lung cancer over 10 years than those who continue smoking. A patient who quit today asks: if I had not quit, would I have developed lung cancer within 10 years?
claim: If this patient had continued smoking instead of quitting today, they would have developed lung cancer within 10 years.
label: CONDITIONAL
causal_structure: Continuing to smoke increases risk, but lung cancer is probabilistic and depends on susceptibility and competing risks (Z).
key_insight: Risk factors shift probabilities; they rarely determine individual outcomes.
hidden_timestamp: What is the patient's baseline 10‑year lung cancer risk and competing mortality risk at the time of quitting?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If the patient has high genetic susceptibility and high cumulative exposure with low competing mortality, continuing smoking could make developing cancer plausible (still not certain).
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If the patient has low susceptibility or high competing mortality (e.g., severe cardiovascular disease), they may not develop lung cancer regardless, making the counterfactual INVALID as a certainty claim.

wise_refusal: This counterfactual is CONDITIONAL: smoking changes the probability of lung cancer, not a deterministic outcome. Without the patient's baseline risk and competing risks, we cannot assert they would have developed cancer.
gold_rationale: Cessation reduces lung cancer risk on average, but individual-level counterfactual outcomes are uncertain. The correct claim is probabilistic: continued smoking would raise the chance of cancer. Whether the patient would develop cancer depends on unobserved heterogeneity (Z) and competing risks, so a certainty claim is not warranted.

scenario: After a minor stroke, patients who receive an MRI within 24 hours (X) often have more 'lesions detected' (Y) than patients who only receive CT. A family asks: if our relative had received an MRI instead of CT, would they have had a larger stroke?
claim: If the patient had received MRI instead of CT, they would have had a larger stroke.
label: CONDITIONAL

Z: Time from symptom onset to imaging

causal_structure: MRI detects smaller infarcts better than CT; imaging modality affects measurement of lesion size, not the underlying biological stroke size.
key_insight: Changing measurement tools can change what you observe without changing reality.
hidden_timestamp: Was the difference due to detection sensitivity (measurement) or did treatment timing change between the MRI vs CT scenarios?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If treatment and timing were identical, MRI would likely show a larger measured lesion due to higher sensitivity, but the true stroke size would be unchanged—so the counterfactual claim is INVALID.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If choosing MRI delayed reperfusion therapy, the true stroke could become larger, making the counterfactual potentially VALID via timing effects.

wise_refusal: This counterfactual is CONDITIONAL: MRI changes detection (measurement) and can also change care timing. Without knowing whether imaging choice altered treatment timing, we cannot attribute a larger stroke to MRI itself.
gold_rationale: Imaging modality primarily affects measurement of lesion size, so a larger observed lesion on MRI may reflect sensitivity rather than a larger biological infarct. However, if obtaining MRI delayed time-sensitive treatment, it could indirectly worsen outcomes. Thus the claim hinges on whether MRI changes only observation or also the causal pathway through treatment delay (Z).
